Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Emergence Of Unique Regional Identity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Adriana Linares-Palma, of the University of Texas at Austin, will undertake research to study identity politics in San Juan Cotzal, Guatemala, during the Postclassic period. She will research why the Ixil Maya have a unique regional identity and how the Ixil Maya responded to K'iche' Maya expansionism during the Late Postclassic period (A.D. 1250-1530) in the Maya highlands of Mesoamerica. The project aims to understand what effect socio-political conflict and migration in the Mesoamerican region had upon people's relationship to landscape, territory, and social identities in Ixil Postclassic communities. To study the development of Ixil identity, research will focus on the regional settlement patterns, architecture, and artifacts of the Ixil, in comparison to those of other Maya groups in the region. Through archaeological, archival, and ethnographic investigation, researchers will examine Ixil settlement patterns and ancient materiality to determine if Ixil people were in isolation or in contact with other Maya groups in the area, and whether they formed networks or maintained autonomy with respect to diverse Maya groups in the area during the Postclassic Period. Linares-Palma will lead a team of students to conduct mapping of the archaeological sites under study as part of their professional development. The research will provide information into how traditional societies adapt within a regional context and interact with other groups.

Research will be conducted at San Juan Cotzal, Quich?, one of three towns of the Ixil region. The researcher and team of students will map all the archaeological sites in order to explore the following questions: do Ixil settlement patterns and materiality reflect isolation from the expansionist tendency of the K'iche' political entity during the Postclassic period? Do they reflect instead contact, autonomy and perhaps even networks with diverse Maya groups of the highlands and lowlands during the Postclassic Period? Through spatial analysis of Ixil architectural configuration, incorporation of contextual data from previous archaeological research, as well as an analysis of ceramics and other artifacts, researchers will compare particular characteristics of the Ixil with other Maya highland and lowland settlements. They will incorporate socio-political organizations of lineages among the Maya highlands, which are visible through architecture, spatial configuration, and settlement patterns. Through archaeological, archival and ethnographic research at San Juan Cotzal, Quiche, Guatemala, researchers will expand on theories of migrations; regional political and cultural conflicts social networks and identity politics. Moreover, researchers will expand on theories of segmentary lineage organization previously proposed for the Maya highlands, as well as contribute to the refinement of previous interpretations of the Ixil region.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research examines how the Ixil political entity behaved facing K´iche´ expansionist tendency for control over resources and territory in highland Guatemala between 1250 A.D. and 1530 A.D. It is important to understand the role of the ancient Ixil during the Postclassic period, in the dynamics and conflicts of the Maya highlands and lowlands. Specifically, this study seeks to understand the socio-political relationships within and outside the Ixil area. During fieldwork, I researched the identity politics of Ixils within the Maya highlands through a participatory mapping project that created an archaeological atlas of San Juan Cotzal. I directed a survey of archaeological sites in collaboration with Ixil University students and the Indigenous Mayoralty of San Juan Cotzal. My team and I documented exposed ancient architecture to analyze settlement patterns within the Ixil cultural landscape. Also, I studied ceramic assemblages we observed during our survey and I revised collections registered by previous research. These materials provide evidence of strong interaction among Postclassic settlements of the Maya Highlands. My archival research for this region was limited. The earliest archives provided scarce information on the colonial period, and mostly information on the 19th century. However, the archives contained information of colonial reductions at the Ixil region and this information is important to understand Ixil territorial organization.

During the participatory mapping, I interviewed locals to document appropriate names for all archaeological sites of Cotzal. Later, I discussed this information with local linguists to revise and correct it. As part of the participatory mapping, this research incorporates important archaeological sites that had never been documented before, and it includes sacred sites that belong to a greater network of places of origin for the communities in Cotzal. Therefore, I interviewed spiritual guides and local people to understand the role of ancient ruins and sacred landscape within their lives and their history.

Preliminary results indicate that the Ixil and other groups of the Maya highlands and lowlands formed networks of socio-political and economic alliances that exceeded the territorial limits of each group. Architectural features provide the evidence of ancient networks of affiliation of the Ixil during the Postclassic period. For example, during my fieldwork I documented the presence of talud-tablero and counseling houses that reflect cultural entanglements among dominant centers of the region and culture exchange, circulation, and predominant social thinking.

This research project would not have been possible without the constant dialogue and negotiations I had with the Indigenous mayors from San Juan Cotzal. They suggested that I conduct this research and they were present in all stages of this project.  I draw from methods and practices that emphasize collaboration between archaeologists and local communities, as part of a committed community-based agenda. The Indigenous Mayoralty, Ixil University, b´alb´atztioxh (spiritual guides), aq´ii´ (day keepers), and myself started a collaboration to discuss possible diverse uses of archaeology in their town, and to learn participatory methodologies for mapping. We created a reflexive and respectful space to dialogue, negotiate and organize schedules, logistics, and conversations about how we were going to build a map containing the location and stories of Ixil archaeological and sacred sites. In such space we were all research partners, as each one of the members collaborated significantly to the results of the mapping project. 

Rights over cultural heritage are very important for people of San Juan Cotzal. They argue that archaeological sites are their own cultural heritage, and that they as Ixils have exclusive rights over their “ruins” rather than the rights that the Guatemalan nation-state claims. Hence, having significant participation in the production of an archaeological atlas is important for the Indigenous Mayoralty of San Juan Cotzal, as part of their commitment to social justice.

The results of this project contribute both to academic debates and directly to the interests of local people. One of the main arguments of participants in this research is that the current literature about Ixil ancient history is limited to academic platforms. The Indigenous mayors from San Juan Cotzal have their own scientific interest in the past as a tool to defend their cultural heritage. By having the knowledge of Ixil socio-political dynamics during the Postclassic period and a complete map of their archaeological and sacred sites, they have evidence to demonstrate Ixil ancestry and support their claim to rights over land and cultural heritage when facing struggles with extractive industries.
